urn:contentItem:5XVP-KJN1-F0J6-J168-00000-00Bushfires 'catastrophic' for wildlife says expert2019-12-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:57ZLexisNexisBushfires 'catastrophic' for wildlife says expertDamon Cronshaw

Bushfires that destroyed massive areas of national park in the Hunter and elsewhere in NSW will have devastated wildlife, Tim Faulkner says.

Almost a million hectares have burnt in national parks within or closely connected to the Hunter, Rural Fire Service data shows.

This includes mega-fires in Yengo, Wollemi and Dharug national parks.

The notorious Wollemi fire, known as the "Gospers Mountain" blaze, has set a record for being the biggest forest fire in Australian history.

Mr Faulkner, the Australian Reptile Park general manager, said the effect of the fires on wildlife had been "catastrophic".

"It's unfathomable," said Mr Faulkner, who is also president of the Aussie Ark wildlife sanctuary in the Barrington Tops.

"This is a native wildlife state of emergency."

National parks have been hit by fire on the NSW east coast from Sydney to the Queensland border.

Federal Environment Minister Sussan Ley said 30 per cent of koalas on the NSW mid-north coast may have died in the fires.

While a big focus has been placed on koalas, many other species have been badly affected.

"When it comes to the hardest hit mammals, we're losing entire populations," Mr Faulkner said.

Mr Faulkner gave brush-tailed rock wallabies and platypuses as examples of species hit hard by the fires.

"Brush-tailed rock wallabies are critically endangered in parts and endangered in others. They had already been pushed within an inch of their lives. They're in real strife," he said.

The Wollemi National Park, stretching from the Hunter to the Blue Mountains, has more than 300 native species of mammals, reptiles, frogs and birds. Yengo National Park is home to a similar number.

Both national parks are part of the Greater Blue Mountains World Heritage Area. The brush-tailed rock-wallaby is a high priority for conservation management in both parks.

The NSW government is spending $100 million over five years to save threatened animals and plants from extinction from 2016 to 2021 under its Saving Our Species program.

Mr Faulkner said the bushfires had put species under further pressure. In some places, the fires had annihilated their habitat.

"I have empathy with government departments. The fires are still burning and staff and resources are committed to those fires," he said.

"Human life, infrastructure and stopping the fires from burning is the priority. But what about the wildlife? So much has been lost already and it won't come back without help."

He said a mass-scale combined effort was "needed now, not later".

"Many of the species affected were already at risk of extinction, such as koalas, brush-tailed rock-wallabies, turtles, quolls and platypus."

He said the effects of the fires on the largely unseen platypus population would be severe.

"People will say bushfires happen and it's natural. Sure, but what about the catastrophic nature of them?

"If it was just these fires and this drought, sure, but you've got all the other compounding effects these species were already suffering."

The country is in the midst of a wildlife catastrophe.

"Australia had the worst mammal extinction rate on Earth long before this fire and drought," he said.

The threatened tiger quoll was another species that the fires would have hammered.

"This entire fire range is tiger quoll habitat. They will have been annihilated.

"You're talking probably 50 to 100 endangered species that have been severely impacted."

Some of the other threatened species known to live in the national parks include the squirrel glider, grey-headed flying-fox, regent honeyeater, grey-crowned babbler, speckled warbler, brown treecreeper, broad-headed snake, black-chinned honeyeater, masked owl, barking owl, turquoise parrot, east-coast freetail-bat, black bittern and brush-tailed phascogale.

The NSW Office of Environment said many wildlife species can endure fires "by maintaining populations in refuge areas or habitats which have not been recently impacted by fire".

"The severity of the current bushfires combined with ongoing drought will have an impact on wildlife, including threatened species," a department spokesperson said.

"The extent of the impact will depend on the intensity of the fire and will vary from location to location."

The spokesperson said the NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service backed "licensed wildlife rehabilitation groups and individuals with funding and support during the search process [for affected wildlife]".

It added that it worked with the "many dedicated wildlife hospitals, carers and rehabilitation centres to care for any injured or displaced wildlife".

Aussie Ark and Australian Reptile Park staff have assessed drought- and fire-affected areas in the greater Barrington region.

"The results witnessed by staff were devastating. The wildlife organisations had to relocate 50 endangered Hunter River turtles from dried up waterways," Mr Faulkner said.

"Ten platypus were found and transferred, with five requiring veterinary care."

They also monitored and provided food drops for brush-tailed rock-wallabies and assessed the possibility of emergency intervention for the critically endangered Manning River turtle.

"Food drops and artificial water stations should happen. This has been well trialled before in areas affected by fire," he said.

"There really needs to be a bigger response, but it's needed now. In six months time, they're all dead."

He said some animals would survive the fires and drought, but they still faced the "massive problem of feral pests".

"Can you imagine how much easier they will be for foxes and cats to hunt?

"The animals are exposed and vulnerable. That's what's happening now."

He said the wildlife crisis needs "a thousand champions" from public-private partnerships, corporations, government, philanthropic and conservation groups and the community.

He said the focus over the summer should be on areas where water had dried up.

"I don't think we can plan on it raining," he said.

He said the fires had caused a "catastrophic loss of biomass" for many common species.

"Where [for example] do the honeyeaters go? What do they eat? Everything is displaced," he said.

He said this catastrophic loss would have a "compounding effect".

"I view it like a tide. The tide is coming, whether it's climate change, pollution, feral pests, fire or drought.

"Every time the animals poke their heads up for a breath of air, bang, another wave hits them."

He wonders whether the forests and species will be able to recover. He was particularly concerned that rainforests and so-called "wet forests" had burned in northern parts of the state.

"We've lost Antarctic beech forest. It's Gondwanian. It's cool temperate forest," he said.

These ancient world-heritage areas stretch in pockets from the Barrington Tops to the Gold Coast. They are the last remnants of the supercontinent Gondwana that broke up about 180 million years ago. Their ecology has been likened to the time of the dinosaurs. Usually these forests are too wet to burn. But sections in northern NSW and southern Queensland burned in the recent fires, highlighting the threat of climate change.

These areas are home to half of Australia's plant species and a third of its birds and mammals. They help protect dozens of threatened species.

He said these types of forests were "not fire resilient".

"When they die, they die."

The Barrington Tops world heritage area has, so far, escaped fire. The Aussie Ark wildlife sanctuary is also in the Barrington Tops. The non-profit organisation establishes predator-proof and fenced sanctuaries for threatened species such as the Tasmanian devil, eastern quoll and long-nosed potoroo. A koala sanctuary is planned to be established.

Mr Faulkner is worried about fire threatening Aussie Ark's species.

"We are in a really complementary spot, on the north-west side of the Barringtons. Fire kind of has to start on us to reach us," he said.

"It's very unlikely to blow our way. There were four fires up there threatening the Barringtons just weeks ago. They were well controlled. It's largely been unscathed."

This was partly down to luck, he said, which "makes the protection of critical habitat all the more important".

He said the same type of fires won't happen again next year because "there's nothing left to burn".

"But the wildlife and people are suffering. The Earth is suffering. This doesn't end when the flames go out," he said.

"What is the response from governments?"

urn:contentItem:5XVP-KJN1-F0J6-J104-00000-00Bushfires 'catastrophic' for wildlife says expert2019-12-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:57ZLexisNexisBushfires 'catastrophic' for wildlife says expertDamon Cronshaw

Bushfires that destroyed massive areas of national park in the Hunter and elsewhere in NSW will have devastated wildlife, Tim Faulkner says.

Almost a million hectares have burnt in national parks within or closely connected to the Hunter, Rural Fire Service data shows.

This includes mega-fires in Yengo, Wollemi and Dharug national parks.

The notorious Wollemi fire, known as the "Gospers Mountain" blaze, has set a record for being the biggest forest fire in Australian history.

Mr Faulkner, the Australian Reptile Park general manager, said the effect of the fires on wildlife had been "catastrophic".

"It's unfathomable," said Mr Faulkner, who is also president of the Aussie Ark wildlife sanctuary in the Barrington Tops.

"This is a native wildlife state of emergency."

National parks have been hit by fire on the NSW east coast from Sydney to the Queensland border.

Federal Environment Minister Sussan Ley said 30 per cent of koalas on the NSW mid-north coast may have died in the fires.

While a big focus has been placed on koalas, many other species have been badly affected.

"When it comes to the hardest hit mammals, we're losing entire populations," Mr Faulkner said.

Mr Faulkner gave brush-tailed rock wallabies and platypuses as examples of species hit hard by the fires.

"Brush-tailed rock wallabies are critically endangered in parts and endangered in others. They had already been pushed within an inch of their lives. They're in real strife," he said.

The Wollemi National Park, stretching from the Hunter to the Blue Mountains, has more than 300 native species of mammals, reptiles, frogs and birds. Yengo National Park is home to a similar number.

Both national parks are part of the Greater Blue Mountains World Heritage Area. The brush-tailed rock-wallaby is a high priority for conservation management in both parks.

The NSW government is spending $100 million over five years to save threatened animals and plants from extinction from 2016 to 2021 under its Saving Our Species program.

Mr Faulkner said the bushfires had put species under further pressure. In some places, the fires had annihilated their habitat.

"I have empathy with government departments. The fires are still burning and staff and resources are committed to those fires," he said.

"Human life, infrastructure and stopping the fires from burning is the priority. But what about the wildlife? So much has been lost already and it won't come back without help."

He said a mass-scale combined effort was "needed now, not later".

"Many of the species affected were already at risk of extinction, such as koalas, brush-tailed rock-wallabies, turtles, quolls and platypus."

He said the effects of the fires on the largely unseen platypus population would be severe.

"People will say bushfires happen and it's natural. Sure, but what about the catastrophic nature of them?

"If it was just these fires and this drought, sure, but you've got all the other compounding effects these species were already suffering."

The country is in the midst of a wildlife catastrophe.

"Australia had the worst mammal extinction rate on Earth long before this fire and drought," he said.

The threatened tiger quoll was another species that the fires would have hammered.

"This entire fire range is tiger quoll habitat. They will have been annihilated.

"You're talking probably 50 to 100 endangered species that have been severely impacted."

Some of the other threatened species known to live in the national parks include the squirrel glider, grey-headed flying-fox, regent honeyeater, grey-crowned babbler, speckled warbler, brown treecreeper, broad-headed snake, black-chinned honeyeater, masked owl, barking owl, turquoise parrot, east-coast freetail-bat, black bittern and brush-tailed phascogale.

The NSW Office of Environment said many wildlife species can endure fires "by maintaining populations in refuge areas or habitats which have not been recently impacted by fire".

"The severity of the current bushfires combined with ongoing drought will have an impact on wildlife, including threatened species," a department spokesperson said.

"The extent of the impact will depend on the intensity of the fire and will vary from location to location."

The spokesperson said the NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service backed "licensed wildlife rehabilitation groups and individuals with funding and support during the search process [for affected wildlife]".

It added that it worked with the "many dedicated wildlife hospitals, carers and rehabilitation centres to care for any injured or displaced wildlife".

Aussie Ark and Australian Reptile Park staff have assessed drought- and fire-affected areas in the greater Barrington region.

"The results witnessed by staff were devastating. The wildlife organisations had to relocate 50 endangered Hunter River turtles from dried up waterways," Mr Faulkner said.

"Ten platypus were found and transferred, with five requiring veterinary care."

They also monitored and provided food drops for brush-tailed rock-wallabies and assessed the possibility of emergency intervention for the critically endangered Manning River turtle.

"Food drops and artificial water stations should happen. This has been well trialled before in areas affected by fire," he said.

"There really needs to be a bigger response, but it's needed now. In six months time, they're all dead."

He said some animals would survive the fires and drought, but they still faced the "massive problem of feral pests".

"Can you imagine how much easier they will be for foxes and cats to hunt?

"The animals are exposed and vulnerable. That's what's happening now."

He said the wildlife crisis needs "a thousand champions" from public-private partnerships, corporations, government, philanthropic and conservation groups and the community.

He said the focus over the summer should be on areas where water had dried up.

"I don't think we can plan on it raining," he said.

He said the fires had caused a "catastrophic loss of biomass" for many common species.

"Where [for example] do the honeyeaters go? What do they eat? Everything is displaced," he said.

He said this catastrophic loss would have a "compounding effect".

"I view it like a tide. The tide is coming, whether it's climate change, pollution, feral pests, fire or drought.

"Every time the animals poke their heads up for a breath of air, bang, another wave hits them."

He wonders whether the forests and species will be able to recover. He was particularly concerned that rainforests and so-called "wet forests" had burned in northern parts of the state.

"We've lost Antarctic beech forest. It's Gondwanian. It's cool temperate forest," he said.

These ancient world-heritage areas stretch in pockets from the Barrington Tops to the Gold Coast. They are the last remnants of the supercontinent Gondwana that broke up about 180 million years ago. Their ecology has been likened to the time of the dinosaurs. Usually these forests are too wet to burn. But sections in northern NSW and southern Queensland burned in the recent fires, highlighting the threat of climate change.

These areas are home to half of Australia's plant species and a third of its birds and mammals. They help protect dozens of threatened species.

He said these types of forests were "not fire resilient".

"When they die, they die."

The Barrington Tops world heritage area has, so far, escaped fire. The Aussie Ark wildlife sanctuary is also in the Barrington Tops. The non-profit organisation establishes predator-proof and fenced sanctuaries for threatened species such as the Tasmanian devil, eastern quoll and long-nosed potoroo. A koala sanctuary is planned to be established.

Mr Faulkner is worried about fire threatening Aussie Ark's species.

"We are in a really complementary spot, on the north-west side of the Barringtons. Fire kind of has to start on us to reach us," he said.

"It's very unlikely to blow our way. There were four fires up there threatening the Barringtons just weeks ago. They were well controlled. It's largely been unscathed."

This was partly down to luck, he said, which "makes the protection of critical habitat all the more important".

He said the same type of fires won't happen again next year because "there's nothing left to burn".

"But the wildlife and people are suffering. The Earth is suffering. This doesn't end when the flames go out," he said.

"What is the response from governments?"

urn:contentItem:5V6G-RPH1-JD34-V0PK-00000-00Benloch fire under control2019-01-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:57ZLexisNexisBenloch fire under controlElspeth Kernebone Chris Pedler

CLICK HERE FOR ROLLING NEWS COVERAGE

UPDATE, 8.46pm:

The CFA has downgraded the threat to residents in areas surrounding the Benloch fire.

An advice message has been issued for Benloch, Pastoria East, Nulla Vale and Baynton.

"There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and monitor conditions," the message says.

Firefighters remain at the scene and will work throughout the night to make the fire safe.

The fire is about 25 hectares in size and has not crossed any roads.

Traffic management points at Feeneys Lane and Kitchenhams Road, Frosts Road and Burke & Wills Track, and Burke & Wills Track and Feeneys Lane have been removed.

All roads are now open.

Smoke will be visible from nearby communities and roads.

UPDATE, 7pm:

The CFA has issued a Watch and Act message for Benloch, Pastoria East, Nulla Vale and Baynton for a bushfire at Kitchenhams Road, Benloch.

The fire is under control and has burnt about 25 hectares. It has not crossed any roads at this stage.

People who live in the warning area and are away from home are advised not to return. Those who are at home have been urged not to wait.

'Leaving now is the safest option,' the message says.

'Conditions may change and get worse very quickly.'

The CFA has advised people to monitor for signs that indicate the situation is changing, including increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility.

"If the situation changes or you feel unsafe you should leave," the message says.

"Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area.

"Emergency services might not be able to help you if you decide to stay."

Traffic management points are in place at Feeneys Lane and Kitchenhams Road; Frosts Road and Burke & Wills Track; and Burke & Wills Track and Feeneys Lane.

UPDATE, 3.50pm:

The bushfire in Kitchenhams Road Benloch has been declared under control.

READ MORE: Homes and lives were under threat as firefighters battled Benloch blaze

2.14pm: The bushfire in Kitchenhams Road, Benloch, is threatening homes and lives as it moves in a westerly direction. Vic Emergency is advising residents in the area to take shelter indoors immediately as the fire is not yet under control.

The next update is expected at 3.10pm, the current warning reads:

"You are in danger and need to act immediately to survive.

The safest option is to take shelter indoors immediately. It is too late to leave.

You should move indoors:

If you cannot get indoors, last resort options include:

If you are travelling:

If you are caught in fire in your car:

Impacts in your area:

If you can smell smoke, please note:

Smoke can affect people's health.

People with pre-existing health problems, heart or lung conditions (including asthma), children, pregnant women and older people are more sensitive to the effects of breathing in smoke.

People with existing heart or lung conditions (including asthma) should follow the treatment plan advised by the doctor.

Health information:

If you need medical advice for burns or exposure to smoke, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.

Anyone experiencing wheezing, chest tightness and difficulty breathing should call Triple Zero (000).

If you cannot smell smoke you are not likely to be exposed to smoke and it will therefore not affect you.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:

www.emergency.vic.gov.au.

VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.

VicEmergency app.

Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).

Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:

The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.

To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.

If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

UPDATE, 2.08pm: A CFA spokesman confirmed three firefighting aircraft are on route to the fire in Benloch.

Four CFA crews are currently on site and working to control the blaze which covers 300 square metres.

A further 12 CFA crews are route to the fire.

The CFA spokesman could not confirmed what started the fire.

EARLIER: An advice message has been issued for Kitchenhams Road as the Country Fire Authority fight a scrub fire that has broken out in Benloch.

The fire covers an area of 300 square metres. Fourteen appliances are attending the fire.

The CFA has advised that there is currently no threat to people in the area, but that they should stay informed and monitor conditions.

Read more: Bushfire survival kits should be ready, severe conditions declared for January 15

Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads.

Crews were called to the scene just after 1pm.

CFA are working alongside police and Forest Fire Management Victoria at the scene.

People in the area should monitor changes including increased wind speed, change in wind direction and smoke or poor visibility that indicate the situation is changing.

Smoke can affect people's health, particularly those with heart or lung conditions, children, pregnant women and elderly people. People with existing medical conditions should follow the treatment plan advised by their doctor.

urn:contentItem:5M8S-THM1-JD3N-519N-00000-00ET is just a big rubber puppet2016-11-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:57ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 27ET is just a big rubber puppetMIRANDA MURPHY, MURPHY'S LORE

Generation X movie classics prove a tougher sell for today's kids

Spoiler alert â€¦ if you haven't seen it; trigger alert â€¦ if it makes you weep like a child.

We've been trying to wean our kids off animated movie schlock like Barbie and the Three Musketeers and Scooby Doo Solves the Kennedy Assassination.

It's not easy; they think that any piece of live-action film is basically the news and doubly boring.

But still we persist. And so we drew up a list of our favourite Gen Xer kids' movies that shaped our development and that we hoped they would love too.

First cab off the rank: ET, The Extra Terrestrial.

Admittedly this movie had extra resonance for me. My father, who worked his socks off, took me to this film in possibly the only father-daughter excursion we had together.

I must have been about eight when I came home from school one weekday to find Dad waiting there. Ominous in itself; I probably thought he'd lost his job.

"We're going to a movie!" he cheerfully announced. This was super odd, but I went along with it anyway, especially since he said it was some newfangled thing called ET.

Off we traipsed. As we were waiting in line my already quite ancient (in my eyes) father recalled the first movie he'd seen, Disney's Snow White, somewhere in late 1930s England.

Now, Dad was a hardened outback doctor. He'd seen stuff in his lifetime that would make your hair turn grey, curl up and pack its bags.

But still the 50-something gent blanched when he recalled how terrified he'd been when he saw the Evil Witch Queen.

That's the power of movies, especially for kids. Good triumphs over evil, orphans defeat the system, horrid comeuppances are delivered to wrongdoers.

When we showed our kids ET, we were prepared with tissues and life lessons. They came in handy for my husband and me, who sobbed like toddlers on the sofa. The kids, however, were strangely unmoved, except when the potplant looked like it needed water.

Were our offspring sociopaths? Why weren't they doubled over with tears at the saddest, loveliest movie ever made?

Turns out they considered ET to be just a big rubber puppet. CGI animation has got that good that anything prior just looks lame.

We've given our childhood movie education a red-hot go, though. They loved Honey, I Shrunk The Kids, The Princess Bride, and the Star Wars movies - although when a major character got killed off our seven-year-old cried "Dad! You've taken me to the wrong movie!" Of course, you've got to be wary of the dark themes at work. Parental guidance is recommended, so when my kids asked to watch Bambi, I was both sentimental and wary.

I briefed them pre-screening on the early, traumatically tragic death of Bambi's mum.

"How does she die?" asked one of them, always keen on the fine print. "Um, I can't remember," I replied. "Maybe in the forest fire."After a bit, one of the kids came bursting in, triumphantly exclaiming: "Mum! You were wrong! Bambi's mum didn't get caught in the fire, she was killed by hunters!"

urn:contentItem:3RV4-37H0-0048-T11J-00000-00<published>1998-01-21T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:42:57Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Racing</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>RACE: RANDWICK WINNER MAKES IT ALL WORTHWHILE FOR DUNN</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Bronwyn Farr</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"> SYDNEY, Jan 21 AAP - It gets lonely in a shoebox-sized jockeys' room far away from the camaraderie of the blokes and svelte 22-year-old Kelly Dunn has more reason than most her age to watch her weight, but victory at Royal Randwick makes these small hardships worthwhile.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Women jockeys remain a minority and few would dispute it's an uphill battle for credibility and acceptance in one of the last real male bastions.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> But when Dunn booted home another winner today the number of high-profile trainers who knocked on the door of her quaintly-named "lady" jockeys' room indicated a groundswell of support for the talented rider.</p><p>"It does get a bit lonely some days, up here in a box with a TV," said Dunn of the room she shares mostly with senior rider Lee Ann Olsen.</p><p> "And I do have to watch my weight as I am naturally about 53kg to 54kg and I try to ride at 50kg.</p><p> "I try to eat three healthy meals a day with lots of fruit, pasta, rice and vegetables.</p><p> "But I ride a winner at Randwick and that will make it all easy for the next month!"</p><p> The first year apprentice has impressed trainer Geoff Maynes who has engaged her four times for three wins including today's surprise victory aboard Forest Fire, her second on the gelding.</p><p> Dunn went very wide in the straight on the 15-1 chance to score the Alexander Mackellar Hcp (1400m) by a decisive 1-3/4 lengths from promising Sound (8-1), with well-supported 11-4 favourite Bound By Silence a further neck away third.</p><p> "I wasn't too happy about being that wide but they weren't going to let me back in - there's no favours out there - and as it turned out I was on the best part of the track, and Forest Fire travelled beautifully all the way," Dunn said.</p><p> Dunn worked briefly as a teacher after graduating from university but the long-time trackwork rider found the lure of racing irresistible and succumbed to trainer Paul Cave's apprenticeship offer last September.</p><p> Her first race ride resulted in a winner, at Kembla Grange on aptly-named Exploding Success, and a mere week later, on September 21 last year, Dunn recorded her first city win aboard the Cave-trained Seto Stayer.</p><p> "She rides all right," said Maynes. "Horses travel for her."</p><p> "I said if she was caught wide not to worry as Forest Fire tends to run away from other horses."</p><p> Dunn, who is accomplished at Tai Kwon Do and uses the discipline to enhance her fitness, has as her immediate ambition to be the first female jockey to outride her claim in Sydney.</p><p> "While I was at uni I rode work for Paul Cave, then I taught for six months then travelled overseas for a year, riding trackwork everywhere, and when I came back Paul talked me into becoming a jockey," she said.</p><p> "Maybe eventually I will go back to teaching, but not right now, I'm having too much fun!"</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3RV4-37H0-0048-T11J-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="470"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:5V5M-69M1-JD3N-52C3-00000-00BORN TO STAND OUT2019-01-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:57ZLexisNexisLIFESTYLEPg. 8BORN TO STAND OUTMIRANDA LUBY

THERE IS NEVER JUST ONE WAY TO ACHIEVE YOUR GOALS. WE MEET SOME OUTSTANDING PEOPLE WHO ARE THE EPITOME OF THIS MANTRA, DETERMINED TO DO THINGS THEIR OWN WAY BY BREAKING THE MOULD AND EXCELLING IN THEIR CHOSEN FIELDS

LILY BROWN THIS DETERMINED SURF COAST WOMAN IS TRAVELLING TO ANTARCTICA IN THE NAME OF FEMALE LEADERSHIP AND THE FIGHT TO SAVE OUR PLANET, WRITES MIRANDA LUBY WHEN Lily Brown was a kid, her mum told her women could do anything. But she didn't always believe it.

"I was taught I could be whatever I wanted if I worked hard," she explains over a coffee at her local Jan Juc cafe.

"But there are so many professions in which women still aren't visible in leadership positions.

"It's one thing to be told you can do something, it's another thing to actually see other women doing it." Now 31, the Community Engagement Ranger is one of 95 women from around the world selected to travel to Antarctica as part of Homeward Bound, a unique initiative which aims to heighten the visibility, influence and impact of women making the decisions that shape our planet.

"When I found out I'd been chosen I was so shocked," she says. "This is a dream come true for me." The program, which runs for 12 months and culminates in the epic voyage down south late next year, develops leadership skills and an understanding of climate change science through a series of workshops both in the lead up to the trip and while surrounded by icebergs, penguins and whales in Antarctica.

The women, who all represent one of the five STEMM fields (science, technology, engineering, mathematics or medicine), will have the chance to see first-hand the influence of human impact on the environment and the global-scale change needed to reverse it.

"I believe women are needed in leadership roles in order to help provide the solutions to the problem of climate change.

"And this program is empowering those women, because mother nature needs her daughters now more than ever." From a young age, Lily was drawn to nature and conservation, spending family holidays by the ocean's edge climbing trees, camping and hiking through the bush.

Inspired by fellow female nature-lovers, she became enthralled with Dian Fossey and Jane Goodall.

"I was obsessed with apes; I wanted to study primatology," Lily says. "And here were some women who were leading their fields in science. I really looked up to them." But in regional Victoria, it was harder for Lily to find role models. "There weren't a lot of women working in field roles outside of metropolitan Melbourne; there still aren't," she explains.

Lily studied a Bachelor of Science majoring in Conservation of Australian Wildlife. She completed her honours in fire ecology and also did a Masters in Teaching.

It was while working as a forest fire fighter, battling bush blazes during the deadly Victorian summers, that she began to experience the misconceptions and imbalance of gender in these types of fields first-hand.

"When I would tell some people what I did, they would say 'what do you mean you're a firefighter? You're a girl!'" Lily says.

"I'd have to explain to them that it's not all about brute force." While working in the remote community of Maningrida in Australia's Northern Territory, she again sought strong, compassionate female leaders to inspire her - and found them.

"I spent some time with the female elders," she says. "They really showed me how important having strong male and female leaders is for a community." Now a Community Engagement Ranger with Parks Victoria, Lily combines her passion for conservation and education to inspire other women and young girls to care for nature and become change-makers in the fight for the environment.

But there's still a long way to go for female leaders, explains Lily, not just in science but all fields.

"Despite making up 45 per cent of the global workforce, women are globally underrepresented in leadership positions," she says.

"Female leaders are still labelled as bossy, mean and aggressive and continue to be asked whether they're planning to have a family or not in job interviews." "I also think it's a bit of a female trait to underestimate our own value. "Despite being in a leadership position now, I still recognise that in myself." This self-doubt is one of the main reasons Lily is looking forward to her Homeward Bound journey.

"Aside from getting to travel to Antarctica, I think meeting all these other like-minded, inspiring women in STEMM industries is going to be a huge boost for me," she says about the other participants from around the world as well as from Victoria, including Zoos Victoria Reproductive Biologist Dr Marissa Parrot and CSRIO Research Scientist Samia Elfekih.

"I think these women are going to show me I can do more than I ever thought possible." When it comes to climate change, though, Lily has no doubts. Something needs to be done in Australia.

"I think there's been total inaction and a big part of that is the current leadership we have and the lack of value they're placing on the planet," she says.

"Scientists know we are really messing this up but that message just isn't getting through to the people who make decisions.

"Part of what Homeward Bound aims to do is empower the whole population to push the government to make the environment a priority."Lily is currently raising money for her Antarctica trip, which is self-funded. You can follow her journey on Instagram at @ranger.lily and donate at chuffed.org/project/ranger-lily

urn:contentItem:5RX1-GN21-DY19-C4R7-00000-00'It will never be the same again': Tathra decimated by fire2018-03-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:57ZLexisNexis'It will never be the same again': Tathra decimated by fireEryk Bagshaw

Malcolm Turnbull has activated the national disaster emergency relief scheme after a fire ripped through the Bega Valley.

Tathra: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has activated the national disaster emergency relief scheme after a fire ripped through the Bega Valley, devastating hundreds of residents in the small community of Tathra.

"It will never be the same again," said one resident of 26 years, Renata Boulter.

House were reduced to shells in the town on the NSW south coast, leaving 69 completely destroyed and locals in emergency accommodation at Bega Showgrounds.

Mr Turnbull pledged to investigate local concerns that they got no warning from emergency service broadcasts, with a dozen residents holed up in Bega telling Fairfax Media they received no notification before police and the Rural Fire Service arrived at their door screaming for them to evacuate.

Megan Morrison, who has lived in the town for 18 years, took her teenage son, two dogs and five guinea pigs with her as she saw the flames rising above her roof.

"The police pulled up at our house and yelled get out of here!" she said, "People didn't realise it was time to get your s--- together and go."

The fire's speed took emergency services by surprise, with a gust of wind taking the blaze up the gully and straight into town, tearing through houses just two blocks west of the town's main street.

Gas bottles exploded across a row of eight houses near Ocean View Terrace, turning a row of sea-facing homes into an inferno.

While many homeowners said they had insurance, the town's renters were left wondering if they would be able to recoup any of their losses.

"I know three friends who don't have any, they are stuffed," said Ms Morrison.

Local MP Mike Kelly, Home Affairs Minister Peter Dutton and Emergency Services Minister Angus Taylor moved on Monday to declare residents would be eligible for the national disaster relief scheme, after the scale of the damage became apparent.

"While houses can be replaced, lives can't," Mr Turnbull said after speaking to residents suddenly made homeless and inspecting the damage in Tathra.

Ms Boulter, who has been stranded in Bega for 24 hours, said the only way to check if her house was still standing was to continually ring her phone at home.

At 5pm it was still ringing through, but "the hardest thing is not knowing what you have lost," she said.

The NSW Premier, Gladys Berejiklian, said she was "confident that every effort was made to tell people at the right time," after hearing criticism of the emergency warning system at the Rural Fire Service briefing centre.

The area is a well-known reception blackspot, raising questions over the reliability of services in emergency situations, which increasingly rely on smart-phone communication.

The nearby mobile tower, which already functions poorly, was one of the first pieces of infrastructure destroyed.

Mr Kelly, who has long had concerns about the area's coverage, told Fairfax Media he was working to get a new Telstra service tower up and running as soon as possible.

Fire Commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons said there was only 100 metres between the fire missing the town all together and the one that destroyed 69 homes.

He said the random nature of the fire was the result of embers raining down on gardens, homes and even the sand dunes.

"Something worked to keep everyone alive," said Commissioner Fitzsimmons. "We are still not counting bodies, or life-threatening injuries and for that we should be forever grateful."

Mr Fitzsimmons said the hundreds of residents that remain sheltered at the Bega Showground evacuation centre would not be allowed to return as long as serious risks remained in the area.

"We are particularly mindful of the amount of asbestos floating around," he said.

Local NSW member Andrew Constance said the damage caused to the town was "heartbreaking''.

"We are not out of this emergency yet," he said, after working through the night with residents.

The Bureau of Meteorology said the forest fire danger index "was the highest on record for March for most areas of the NSW south coast from Nowra southwards, as well as far east Gippsland and parts of the Monaro".

Mr Turnbull said he was "disappointed the Greens would try to politicise an event like this," after Greens leader Richard Di Natale earlier said the conditions were caused by climate change.

More than 10 fires remained uncontained on Monday night, but showers should bring relief to emergency services on Tuesday when residents are hoping to be allowed back in.

urn:contentItem:5FW1-H281-JC0X-K3B5-00000-00CIS:Fire rages near Chernobyl nuclear site2015-04-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:57ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSCIS:Fire rages near Chernobyl nuclear site

  UKRAINE FIRE
   KIEV, April 28 AFP - A forest fire has broken out near the Chernobyl plant in Ukraine, the scene of the world's worst civil nuclear disaster in 1986, but poses no danger to the site.


   "The fire is at a distance of 15 to 20 kilometres from Chernobyl," said Maya Rudenko, a spokeswoman for the plant, adding there was "no problem" there.
   However, Interior Minister Arsen Avakov warned "the high flames and sudden gusts of wind mean there is a serious risk that the fire could spread."
   The area around Chernobyl was evacuated after the 1986 blast and the last reactor there shut down in 2000 but some personnel still operate in the exclusion zone, where work is underway to lay a new seal over the reactor site.
   Avakov said the fire had spread over some 400 hectares near the plant, which lies around 100 kilometres from the Ukrainian capital Kiev.
   Around 200 firefighters with scores of vehicles were battling the inferno and aircraft were dumping water on the flames, the state emergency services said.
   A state nuclear inspection official says that "the level of radiation at the Chernobyl plant has not changed".
   The fire comes just two days after Ukrainians marked 29 years since the Chernobyl nuclear disaster.
   The explosion of reactor number four on April 26, 1986, spewed poisonous radiation over large parts of Europe, particularly Ukraine, Belarus and Russia.
   The human toll of the disaster is still disputed.
   United Nations experts officially recognised 31 deaths among plant workers and firefighters directly linked to the blast.
   But environmental group Greenpeace has suggested there could be around 100,000 additional deaths from cancer caused by the disaster.
   The Soviet authorities of the time dispatched hundreds of thousands of people to put out the fire and clean the site, without proper protection.
   They hastily laid over the reactor site a concrete cover dubbed "the sarcophagus", which is now cracking and must be replaced.
   Ukraine's President Petro Poroshenko on Sunday inspected ongoing work on a new 20,000-tonne steel cover - a project estimated to cost more than two billion euros ($A2.8 billion).
   It is financed by international donations managed by the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD).
   The structure will contain technology that will act beneath the cover to decontaminate the area once the steel layer is in place. Officials say the new cover will last for 100 years.
   AFP evt

urn:contentItem:5FRX-XK61-JD34-V08T-00000-00PREPARATIONS are underway to prepare state forests2015-04-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:57ZLexisNexisEARLY GENERAL NEWSPg. 8PREPARATIONS are underway to prepare state forestsTracey Fairhurst

PREPARATIONS are underway to prepare state forests surrounding the Hastings for this year's fire season with hazard reduction burns to reduce the fuel load over the next few months.

Around seven kilometres of forest trails have been repaired and close to 50 tonnes of rubbish have been removed from Broken Bago State Forest in preparation for a 676 hectare hazard reduction burn to be completed by Forestry Corporation of NSW forest fire fighters.

Forestry Corporation's Wauchope-based Protection Forester Mick Wilson said the hazard reduction burn will be completed as soon as weather conditions are favourable to protect the Wauchope community and the forest from the risk of intense wildfire next fire season.

"There's a narrow window of opportunity to safely complete hazard reduction burns, when it's not too hot or damp and the wind conditions limit the impact of smoke on neighbours so if we get the right conditions we will need to move quickly to complete the burn before the window closes," Mr Wilson said.

"The hazard reduction burn will stretch from Cameron Street (Bago Road) west to the Wauchope cemetery. We have done all our preparation, including upgrading access tracks, removing what was mainly illegally dumped rubbish and advising our forest neighbours. We're now just waiting for favourable weather.

"We expect the burn will take several days to complete, but we may need to return a few times to complete the entire burn if we don't get a stretch of good weather. If we don't get the ideal conditions, we may need to reschedule some or all of the work until spring.

"While Forestry Corporation fire fighters will carefully monitor all controlled burns to ensure they stay within cleared containment lines, we do ask people to pay attention to any signs in the forest or instructions from staff and stay away from any burning or recently burnt areas for their own safety.

"Information about the progress of the burn will be available through the Rural Fire Service's Fires Near Me website and app."

Forestry Corporation is responsible for more than 2.2 million hectares of native and planted forests and has been formally involved in fire-fighting in NSW for almost 100 years.

For more information about hazard reduction burns, contact the Forestry Corporation Wauchope Office on 02 6585 3744 or visit the Rural Fire Service's Fires Near Me website atwww.rfs.nsw.gov.au/fire-information/fires-near-me.

urn:contentItem:7VNC-SYY0-Y9Y8-S2DK-00000-00CFA defends fire warnings2009-05-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:57ZLexisNexisCFA defends fire warnings

The Country Fire Authority chief Russell Rees has told the Royal Commission into Victoria's Bushfires that the anticipated weather changes were adequately conveyed in warnings issued on Black Saturday.

Mr Rees is currently giving evidence at the first formal hearing of the Royal Commission in Melbourne.

Responding to a question regarding whether the warnings issued across the state on February 7 sufficiently took into account the predicted meteorological conditions, Mr Rees said:

"To the best of my knowledge, yes I do say that, remembering that we gave a lot of information prior to that day about the upcoming weather conditions."

He told the commission he was not directly responsible for the warnings given to the public, but if he had thought the warnings were insufficient, he would have tried to fix the warnings by delegating the task.

The hearing began with a minute's silence to honour the 173 victims of Black Saturday.

The bushfires on February 7 also left thousands homeless.

Mr Rees was asked why the measure known as the forest fire danger index was not made available to the public.

He said that number alone would not necessarily help people better understand the fire.

He said it made more sense to talk in terms of extreme fire danger.

Mr Rees conceded giving the forest fire danger index along with an accompanying explanation would be feasible.

Mapping the fires

Mr Rees told the commission he was not aware fire experts were predicting the course of the fires as they unfolded on Black Saturday, even though the experts were in the same building as him.

He was asked whether the fire control centre did anything on February 7 to predict the course of that fire that started in Kilmore East, north of Melbourne.

The fire chief said he was not aware of it on the day but he now believes fire behaviour specialists might have produced a map.

"I was aware that fire behaviour experts did that work. I was not aware that they did it on that day," he said.

The commission heard Mr Rees joined the CFA in 1978 as a career firefighter, and has been the chief of CFA for almost eight years.

"In essence my role is by virtue to have control of all fire brigades - I do that by delegation," Mr Rees told the commission.

The commission heard that on 7 February Mr Rees' operational duty was to be kept informed of events, as well as to inform the Minister for Police and Emergency Services, and other government agencies.

"My position is not to direct the response of individual trucks or brigades," he said.

He said on February 7 his main duty was to ensure that for each of those new fire outbreaks, an incident management procedure was put in place.

The commission heard the CFA is volunteer based and has 59,000 registered volunteers.

"They vary in terms of their degree of activity."

He says approximately 30,000 of those respond to fires, while thousands of others fill support roles such as administration or general support.

Earlier, the commissioners heard from Luke Corbett, a planning officer from the Country Fire Authority (CFA).

Mr Corbett described to the commissioners how a Google Map has been built to trace the February 7 fires, including the map's limitations relating to accurate location inputs.

urn:contentItem:7VH0-HJX1-2RYX-10T6-00000-00Fires beyond control - Stay or go order misled people: QC2009-04-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:57ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 11Fires beyond control - Stay or go order misled people: QCNorrie Ross

BLACK Saturday's 173 victims were left defenceless in the face of an inferno that created fireballs of atomic force.

The Victorian Bushfires Royal Commission was told yesterday that the state's fire warning system broke down and that people remained in their homes unaware of the looming danger.

Counsel assisting the commission, Jack Rush QC, said the ``stay or go early'' warning system might have misled people who did not understand what they were facing.

The effectiveness of the ``000'' emergency system, radio and internet warnings would also come under close scrutiny.

``There will be evidence to suggest that accurate and timely information was not available during 7 February, 2009,'' Mr Rush said.

``Why would a resident of any of the fire affected regions implement the `go' part of the policy if they were not aware of any fire threat?

``Persons who chose to stay and defend their properties did so entirely unaware of the severity, the extremity, the intensity of the fires they would face.''

The opening day of the commission was dogged by more complaints that individual victims were being denied the right to give evidence in person.

Mat Tinkler, acting executive director of the Public Interest Law Clearing House, said applications to be heard from the 30 individuals and communities he represented were rejected.

But Victorian Premier John Brumby refused to buy into the argument over representation.

``I'm not going to comment on the specific decisions made by the commission. I made it very clear that I wanted this to be a commission for the people, I wanted to have the broadest possible terms of reference and that's what we put through the Parliament,'' Mr Brumby said.

In his opening, Mr Rush said the McArthur Forest Fire Danger index had predicted February 7 would be the worst fire danger day ever in Victoria.

According to the index a figure of 50 was considered ``extreme'', but on Black Saturday it ranged between 120 and 180.

In such catastrophic conditions normal warnings became useless.

``The risk that the index indicated carried with it the potential of a fire that could not be fought,'' he said.

Mr Rush said that the first issues considered by the commission would be the warnings and the ``stay or go early'' adopted across Australia.

An expert will give evidence to the commission that people have no knowledge of the triggers of when to leave early and when it is too late to leave.

Mr Rush said the maximum intensity that a forest fire can be controlled is expressed as 4000 kilowatts per metre.

On Black Saturday the intensity reached 100,000 kilowatts per metre.

``Not only the intensity of the fire, the heat of the fire, but its speed was phenomenal,'' Mr Rush said. ``Fire spotted kilometres ahead, fireballs seemingly of atomic force came before the fire.

``Such fires create their own weather and are beyond the most sophisticated attempts to control them.''

Mr Rush said the primary concern of the commission would be to make recommendations that save lives.

He said charred paddocks were already turning green and rebuilding had started but it was the enormous human cost that must be the priority.

``The permanent scarring of individuals, the loss of families and communities, is something that can never be replaced or rebuilt,'' he said.

Mr Rush said fuel reduction would also be a major issue in a complex permit system.

urn:contentItem:5FRX-XK61-JD34-V06B-00000-00PREPARATIONS are underway to prepare state forests2015-04-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:57ZLexisNexisEARLY GENERAL NEWSPg. 8PREPARATIONS are underway to prepare state forestsTracey Fairhurst

PREPARATIONS are underway to prepare state forests surrounding the Hastings for this year's fire season with hazard reduction burns to reduce the fuel load over the next few months.

Around seven kilometres of forest trails have been repaired and close to 50 tonnes of rubbish have been removed from Broken Bago State Forest in preparation for a 676 hectare hazard reduction burn to be completed by Forestry Corporation of NSW forest fire fighters.

Forestry Corporation's Wauchope-based Protection Forester Mick Wilson said the hazard reduction burn will be completed as soon as weather conditions are favourable to protect the Wauchope community and the forest from the risk of intense wildfire next fire season.

"There's a narrow window of opportunity to safely complete hazard reduction burns, when it's not too hot or damp and the wind conditions limit the impact of smoke on neighbours so if we get the right conditions we will need to move quickly to complete the burn before the window closes," Mr Wilson said.

"The hazard reduction burn will stretch from Cameron Street (Bago Road) west to the Wauchope cemetery. We have done all our preparation, including upgrading access tracks, removing what was mainly illegally dumped rubbish and advising our forest neighbours. We're now just waiting for favourable weather.

"We expect the burn will take several days to complete, but we may need to return a few times to complete the entire burn if we don't get a stretch of good weather. If we don't get the ideal conditions, we may need to reschedule some or all of the work until spring.

"While Forestry Corporation fire fighters will carefully monitor all controlled burns to ensure they stay within cleared containment lines, we do ask people to pay attention to any signs in the forest or instructions from staff and stay away from any burning or recently burnt areas for their own safety.

"Information about the progress of the burn will be available through the Rural Fire Service's Fires Near Me website and app."

Forestry Corporation is responsible for more than 2.2 million hectares of native and planted forests and has been formally involved in fire-fighting in NSW for almost 100 years.

For more information about hazard reduction burns, contact the Forestry Corporation Wauchope Office on 02 6585 3744 or visit the Rural Fire Service's Fires Near Me website atwww.rfs.nsw.gov.au/fire-information/fires-near-me.

urn:contentItem:54GM-7551-JD6G-40W3-00000-00Food, and family fun at Mamre House2011-10-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:57ZLexisNexisNEWS - GENERALFood, and family fun at Mamre House

Mamre Homestead will turn into a foodies' paradise on Sunday for the Mamre Good Living Festival. Now in its 22nd year, what started off as a garage sale and art/craft show has grown into an event which is now treats.

Proceeds go towards continuing the Mamre Project helping African refugees, young people and job-seekers. ABC Radio 702 presenter Simon Marnie will broadcast his show live from Mamre Homestead, Costa Georgiadis from SBS show Costa's Garden Odyssey will also be there and the pair will return to Mamre on October 30 for the 100 Mile Dinner. The theme of this year's dinner is Forest, Fire and Drums. Mt Druitt TAFE hospitality students, such as Rod Carroll (pictured) will serve the meal and prepare dessert on the night. ''It's part of the Crave Sydney International Food Festival. More than 5000 attended last year's fun. Mamre development worker Sharon Holstein promises a great family day with food produce stalls, wine tasting, pony rides, arts/crafts, children's activities and live entertainment. Turkish and Asian cuisine, Belgian waffles, Devonshire tea and a barbecue will offer a tasty about eating fresh, local produce sourced from a 160-kilometre radius,'' Ms Holstein said. ''Being part of Crave means we can attract people from outside the area.'' 100 Mile Dinner tickets are $100, which includes three courses, beer, wine and soft drinks. Admission for Sunday is $3 adults, children free.

urn:contentItem:5J18-2YY1-JD34-V12S-00000-00A PREOLENNA craftsman has lost...2016-02-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:57ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 18A PREOLENNA craftsman has lost...

A PREOLENNA craftsman has lost the bulk of his handmade timber instruments to fires which raged across the region just weeks out from a major exhibition.

On January 21 a series of spot fires broke out across the road from Duncan Sproule's property at Preolenna.

Mr Sproule has supplied wood to Australia's largest guitar makers and spent years honing his craft as a luthier, a maker of stringed instruments.

He was one of nine artists selected to have their work exhibited at the Maker's Workshop in Burnie in February 2016.

"It is believed the fire started on the side of the road," Mr Sproule said.

"I can't say in all truth what it was, but the investigator nailed down where it started and it may have been embers or a cigarette butt.

"Two days prior to that I had just done the induction for the Maker's Workshop so in my front shed I had the 94 completed ukulele kits ready to go.

"I was having a power nap, it was a hot day, the fires in the area were so bad it was so smokey everywhere and so we were all indoors with the doors closed.

"I heard a crack and a bang of the fire, that is what alerted me, and I went 'that's a fire,' and I sat up and my daughter stormed into the room and said Dad, the shed is on fire."

Mr Sproule watched on as all his preparation for the exhibition went up in flames.

He lost 94 completed ukulele kits as well as specially designed ukuleles and priceless rare wood, instruments and tools.

Mr Sproule had spent about 10 weeks preparing the kits and each one was valued at $249.

"There is something about a man in his shed. I know what it is like as a man to make something from scratch with your hands," Mr Sproule said.

"I wanted to take a product, for example timber, from the cradle to the grave. That process has taken me 12 years to find out how to luthier."

A spokesperson for The University of Tasmania Maker's Program said Mr Sproule was due to display his wares last week until his stock was destroyed.

"The university is keen to do whatever we can to support him to re-establish his studio practice, and eagerly await his return to the Makers' Program," the spokesperson said.

Mr Sproule hopes to get back to work creating new instruments for the exhibition and is thankful the fire didn't spread further.

"I am so impressed with our volunteer firefighters they were just fantastic, they really stopped a forest fire at my place."

Woodworker Duncan Sproule with a couple of his native timber ukuleles he managed to save when his Preolenna workshop was destroyed by fire.

urn:contentItem:5J18-2YY1-JD34-V103-00000-00Fire blow for craftsman2016-02-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:57ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6Fire blow for craftsmanLUCY SWINNEN

A MUSICAL instrument craftsman has lost the bulk of his handmade timber creations to fires that raged across the region just weeks out from a major exhibition.

On January 21, a series of spot fires broke out across the road from Duncan Sproule's property at Preolenna.

Mr Sproule has supplied wood to Australia's largest guitar makers and spent years honing his craft as a luthier, a maker of stringed instruments.

He was one of nine artists selected to have their work exhibited at the Makers' Workshop in Burnie this month.

"It is believed the fire started on the side of the road. I can't say in all truth what it was, but the investigator nailed down where it started and it may have been embers or a cigarette butt," Mr Sproule said.

"Two days prior to that I had just done the induction for the Makers' Workshop, so in my front shed I had the 94 completed ukulele kits ready to go.

"I was having a power nap, it was a hot day, the fires in the area were so bad it was so smokey everywhere and so we were all indoors with the doors closed.

"I heard a crack and a bang of the fire - that is what alerted me, and I went, 'That's a fire!' And I sat up and my daughter stormed into the room and said, 'Dad, the shed is on fire!"'

Mr Sproule watched on helplessly as all his preparation for the exhibition - his time, love and care put in to creating the instruments - went up in flames.

He lost a total of 94 completed ukulele kits as well as specially designed ukuleles and priceless rare wood, instruments and tools.

Mr Sproule had spent about 10 weeks preparing the kits and each one was valued at $249.

"There is something about a man in his shed. I know what it is like as a man to make something from scratch with your hands," Mr Sproule said.

"I wanted to take a product, for example timber, from the cradle to the grave. That process has taken me 12 years to find out how to luthier."

A spokesperson for the University of Tasmania Makers' Program said Mr Sproule was due to display his wares last week until his stock was destroyed in the bushfire.

"The university is keen to do whatever we can to support him to re-establish his studio practice, and eagerly await his return to the Makers' Program," the spokesperson said.

Mr Sproule is hoping to get back to work creating new instruments for the exhibition and is thankful the fire didn't spread further.

"I am so impressed with our volunteer firefighters; they were just fantastic, they really stopped a forest fire at my place."

urn:contentItem:5FMY-C071-JD6G-4503-00000-00HR burns planned in local State forests2015-03-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:57ZLexisNexisNEWSHR burns planned in local State forestsStan Gorton

THE Forestry Corporation of NSW is about to commence hazard reduction burns in up to 20,000 hectares of State forests near Narooma, Bega, Eden and Batemans Bay to protect against wildfires.

Forest Protection Supervisor Julian Armstrong said hazard reduction burns were a key part of Forestry Corporation's preparation for fire season each year and were coordinated with other agencies including the National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Rural Fire Service.

'Fire season has just wrapped up for another year, which means it's time to start preparing for next summer,' Mr Armstrong said.

'While we've just had a relatively mild fire season, the coastal strip between Nowra and the Victorian border is one of the most fire-prone regions of Australia and managing fuel levels by completing hazard reduction burns is critical to our capacity to manage wildfires over summer.

'There's a narrow window of opportunity to safely complete hazard reduction burns, when it's not too hot or damp and the wind conditions limit the impact of smoke on neighbours, so we will be taking advantage of favourable conditions over the coming months to reduce fuel in local forests.

'We will also be burning recently harvested areas to remove flammable material such as leaves and small limbs and create a rich seed bed that promotes the natural regeneration of the forest.

'Burning will start in areas that are not too wet and move to drier areas as winter approaches.

'While Forestry Corporation fire fighters will carefully monitor all controlled burns to ensure they stay within containment lines, we do ask people to pay attention to any signs in the forest or instructions from staff and stay away from any burning or recently burnt areas for their own safety.

'Forest fire fighters play an important role fighting fires in the region's State forests, but fire prevention is a fundamental part of our role and is a vital way to mitigate the threat of a bad fire season in future years.

'Over the winter months we will also be investing in training fire fighting staff, maintaining and upgrading equipment, improving key forest roads for rapid access and manning fire towers to aid rapid fire detection and quick response next fire season.'

Forestry Corporation is responsible for more than 2.2 million hectares of native and planted forests and has been formally involved in fire-fighting in NSW for almost 100 years.

For more information about hazard reduction burns, contact the Forestry Corporation Batemans Bay Office on 1300 880 548.

urn:contentItem:5BFG-RBS1-JCM0-625B-00000-00Monaro graziers swelter through driest start to summer in 11 years2014-02-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:42:57ZLexisNexisMonaro graziers swelter through driest start to summer in 11 yearsAdrienne Francis

Extreme hot and dry conditions across southern New South Wales have prompted the largest sheep sale in recent years.

An estimated 17,000 sheep went under the hammer on Tuesday at the Cooma Saleyards.

Some livestock commentators described it as the largest yarding since 2007.

Cooma-Monaro Shire mayor Dean Lynch says the deteriorating conditions for livestock and ongoing fires are putting many graziers on edge.

"We are running out of feed again [so] for most producers it's a worrying time," he said.

"We are quite privileged here where we probably haven't experienced the dry conditions up until now.

"I have seen times a lot tougher here than at the moment, it is not panic stations."

Cooma grazier Jan Sands says it is a worrying time for producers.

"If we don't get the winter break now we won't have the feed and then we will be fighting the snow to try and feed sheep," she said.

The Bureau of Meteorology says the Cooma region has recorded the driest start to summer since December 2002 and January 2003.

On Saturday the town recorded its warmest February day with 38.6 degrees.

Overall the region is experiencing the fourth-warmest start to summer since 1973.

A forest fire north of Cooma has also burnt 2,000 hectares in recent days.

As surface water evaporates, survival now lies underground.

Mr Lynch says while Monaro is not officially in drought, it is adding its voice to changes to drought relief.

"I don't believe that welfare is the answer in drought times," he said.

"I believe the government should put processes in place to enable farmers to conserve and make money during the good times."

Ms Sands says she would like Federal Agriculture Minister Barnaby Joyce to visit the Monaro region.

Senator Joyce has been touring Queensland and NSW properties visiting drought-affected farmers.

"Come down and see us during winter and see how bad it is for us down here on the Monaro," she said.

While fear of a return to drought looms large, the weather bureau's three-month outlook has equal odds for drier or wetter conditions.
